column4: hi guys, say I want to do a simple copy/paste task in nautilus but it requires root permission , isn't there any keyboard combination that'll let me enter the root password instead of going to the terminal and entering sudo ?

guys which room should I log into to get help about nautilus ?
why are you trying to write to a folder owned by root?
agrajag : I have openttd and theres a new version online that I've downloaded so I want to overwrite my older files in the /usr/share/games folder
did you download and build the source, or did you get a package file?
arajag : I downloaded the binaries
so you have a .deb file, or what?
: why is that ?
Which package did you get?
agrajag : no a zipped archive
It's a pretty bad idea to go messing around with your /usr directory
Can't you just run the program from your home directory, or remove openttd using the package manager and then istall what you have in /opt or /usr/local?
agrajag : I can run it from my home folder but then I'll be having two version on my ubuntu , one old version which is installed and one unzipped version which I have to navigate to get to
arajag : I just want to overwrite my older files with ease
so uninstall the one you have, and install the one you downloaded to /usr/local/games
agrajag : ok how do I install ?
/usr/local is for stuff not installed by the package manager
I don't know, are there instuctions in the archive?
a file named INSTALL or something similar?
agrajag : its a zipped game , I just unzip it and run it, theres no install option
there is a readme file
agrajag: but the one in the repositories installs an older version
so uninstall that one, extract this one to /usr/local/games/openttd, and make a symlink from the openttd binary there to /usr/bin/openttd
